text: And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual. So when someone tells you to quit your job and chase your dreams, or they tell you to sit tight and grind through and build some experience before you go off and go start the company that you've always been thinking about starting, which piece of advice do you actually take? Right? A lot of it depends on your situation, what you're considering, what skills and experience you actually have, and curiosity loops actually are this way of really thinking about how do you make your advice contextual.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada about curiosity loops and why they're better than traditional advice-seeking. A curiosity loop is when you ask the same question to 10-15 people to gather diverse perspectives rather than relying on one person's opinion. Ada explains that most advice fails not because of bad intentions, but because it lacks context for your specific situation - what worked for one person may not apply to your circumstances.
text_ko: 문제는 그 조언이 악의적이라서가 아니라 맥락이 빠져 있어서예요. 그래서 누군가 '직장을 그만두고 꿈을 쫓아라'라거나 '일단 버티면서 경험을 쌓고 난 뒤에 창업해라'라고 하면, 어느 쪽 조언을 따라야 할까요? 많은 게 본인의 상황, 지금 고려하는 것들, 그리고 실제로 가진 스킬과 경험에 달려 있어요. 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)는 바로 조언을 어떻게 상황에 맞게 만들지 고민하는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 这些建议之所以不好，不是因为出发点不好，而是因为缺乏具体情境。比如有人跟你说辞职去追梦想，或者有人告诉你先熬着积累经验，等有了经验再去创业做你一直想做的公司，那你到底该听哪个建议呢？对吧？很大程度上取决于你的具体情况，你在考虑什么，你实际有什么技能和经验，而好奇心循环(curiosity loops)其实就是一种思考方式，帮你把建议变得更有针对性。
text_es: Y el problema no es que tengan malas intenciones, sino que les falta contexto. Entonces cuando alguien te dice "renuncia a tu trabajo y persigue tus sueños", o te dice "aguanta ahí y sigue echándole ganas, gana experiencia antes de irte a crear esa empresa en la que siempre has pensado", ¿cuál consejo sigues realmente? ¿No? Mucho depende de tu situación, lo que estés considerando, qué habilidades y experiencia tengas en realidad, y los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son precisamente esta forma de pensar en cómo hacer que tus consejos tengan contexto.

text: When I reflect back on what works across my early career, it really comes down in a nutshell to this career concept of explore and exploit. You're either in a mode of explorer where you have a bunch of unknowns and you're testing to see whether or not you like it, how well it works, whether or not it fits for you. Or you're exploiting, where you actually have found something that's really rich and really deep and then you're just trying to get more.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada what advice she has for early career professionals based on her rapid rise from entry-level at Microsoft to SVP at SurveyMonkey in seven years. Ada explains her framework of 'explore and exploit' - early in your career you should explore different roles and industries to find what you enjoy, then once you find something valuable, exploit it by going deep and building expertise in that area.
text_ko: 제 초반 커리어를 돌이켜보면, 결국 한마디로 정리하면 '탐색(explore)과 활용(exploit)'이라는 커리어 개념이에요. 어떤 때는 탐색 모드로, 모르는 게 많아서 이 일이 내가 좋아하는지, 잘 되는지, 나한테 맞는지 이것저것 시도해보는 시기예요. 반대로 활용 모드일 땐 이미 정말 깊고 풍부한 무언가를 찾았기 때문에 그걸 더 확장하고 더 많은 성과를 얻으려고 해요.
text_zh: 回头看我职业生涯初期什么管用，说白了就是一个概念：探索和深挖(explore and exploit)。你要么处在探索模式，面对一堆未知的东西，试试看自己喜不喜欢，效果怎么样，适不适合自己。要么就是在深挖，你已经找到了真正有价值、有深度的东西，然后就是想办法挖得更深。
text_es: Cuando pienso en lo que me funcionó al principio de mi carrera, al final todo se reduce a este concepto: explorar y explotar. O estás en modo explorador, donde tienes un montón de incógnitas y estás probando a ver si te gusta, qué tal funciona, si es lo tuyo o no. O estás explotando, donde ya encontraste algo que realmente vale la pena y tiene mucho potencial, y entonces simplemente tratas de sacarle el máximo provecho.

text: And one of the big reasons why I think curiosity loops are really useful is that it really fights the fact that there's a lot of bad advice out there. And it's not bad because it's not well-intentioned, but it's bad because it's not contextual.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada when to use curiosity loops versus just asking friends for advice. Ada explains that curiosity loops come in both heavyweight (structured email to 10+ people) and lightweight (casually asking the same question to multiple people over time) versions. She emphasizes that curiosity loops help combat bad advice, which isn't bad due to poor intentions but because it lacks context for your specific situation.
text_ko: 제가 호기심 루프(curiosity loop)가 정말 유용하다고 생각하는 큰 이유 중 하나는, 이게 세상에 널린 잘못된 조언들에 맞서는 데 도움이 되기 때문이에요. 그 조언들이 의도가 나쁘다기보다는 맥락이 없어서 문제가 되는 경우가 많거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得好奇心循环(curiosity loop)特别有用，主要原因之一就是能帮我们对付那些糟糕的建议。这些建议问题不在于出发点不好，而是缺乏具体情境。
text_es: Y una de las razones principales por las que creo que los bucles de curiosidad (curiosity loops) son súper útiles es que realmente combaten el hecho de que hay muchísimos malos consejos por ahí. Y no digo que sean malos porque la gente tenga mala fe, sino que el problema es que no tienen contexto.

text: I think that there are heavyweight and lightweight ways to use this. So the heavyweight way was what I just exemplified by saying, I sent an email and I made a doc. And on the other side, I had all of this really interesting and rich data. The lightweight way to do this is really just make it your ongoing theme of what you're curious about as you interact with people.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada about the structure of curiosity loops and when to use them versus not. Ada describes two approaches: heavyweight involves sending structured emails to gather formal feedback on decisions, while lightweight means casually asking the same question to different people in regular conversations. She explains this helps you gather diverse perspectives on important decisions rather than relying on single sources of advice.
text_ko: 이걸 쓰는 데는 무거운 방식(heavyweight way)과 가벼운 방식(lightweight way)이 있다고 생각해요. 제가 방금 예로 든 무거운 방식은 이메일을 보내고 문서를 만들었다고 말한 그런 방식이고, 반면 거기에는 정말 흥미롭고 풍부한 데이터가 쌓여 있었어요. 가벼운 방식은 사람들과 대화할 때 무엇이 궁금한지 그걸 계속 관심을 두는 주제로 삼는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得这个方法有重量级和轻量级两种用法。重量级的做法就是我刚才举的例子，发邮件、做文档，然后收集到很多有意思的丰富数据。轻量级的做法其实就是把它当作一个持续的主题，平时和人打交道的时候，带着这种好奇心去了解。
text_es: Creo que hay maneras más pesadas y más ligeras de hacer esto. La manera pesada fue lo que acabo de ejemplificar diciendo, mandé un email e hice un documento. Y del otro lado, tenía toda esta información súper interesante y rica. La manera ligera de hacerlo es simplemente convertirlo en tu tema constante de qué te da curiosidad mientras interactúas con la gente.

text: It's a terrible outcome to wake up one day and be late career and feel trapped because you have a certain lifestyle or a certain expectations of the people around you that you have to go work this job, but then you look at yourself in the mirror and you're not happy going in there. I think that's a terrible trap that we should all try to avoid as we navigate our career paths and find the thing that's most optimal for us, which is usually a mix of career success, but also meaningfulness and alignment in the work that we're doing with our values.
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Ada is discussing the importance of making career decisions based on personal values rather than external expectations. She emphasizes that optimizing only for resume-building and impressive roles can lead to a trap where you wake up later in your career feeling unhappy despite external success. The key is finding work that balances career advancement with personal fulfillment and alignment with your core values.
vocabulary_highlights: look at yourself in the mirror
text_ko: 어느 날 문득 커리어 후반(late career)에 접어들어 ‘이 생활 수준 때문에, 주변 사람들의 기대 때문에 이 직장을 계속해야 해’라고 느끼며 갇혀 있다고 깨닫는 건 정말 끔찍해요. 그런데 거울을 봤을 때 출근하는 자신이 행복하지 않다면 더더욱 그래요. 저는 이런 함정은 커리어 경로(career paths)를 걸어가면서 모두가 피하려고 노력해야 한다고 생각해요. 보통 우리에게 가장 잘 맞는 건 커리어 성공(career success)뿐 아니라 일의 의미와 우리 가치관(values)에 부합하는 것이 섞여 있는 경우예요.
text_zh: 最怕的就是有一天醒来发现自己职业生涯都快到头了，却感觉被困住了，因为你已经习惯了某种生活方式，或者周围的人对你有某种期待，你不得不继续干这份工作。但是每天照镜子的时候，你根本不想去上班，一点都不开心。我觉得这是个很可怕的陷阱，我们在规划职业道路的时候都应该尽量避免。要找到最适合自己的那个平衡点，通常就是事业成功和工作的意义感要兼顾，做的事情要跟自己的价值观合拍。
text_es: Es terrible despertar un día ya avanzado en tu carrera y sentirte atrapado porque tienes cierto estilo de vida o porque la gente a tu alrededor espera que sigas trabajando en ese puesto, pero cuando te ves al espejo no estás contento de ir a trabajar. Creo que es una trampa horrible que todos deberíamos tratar de evitar mientras vamos construyendo nuestra carrera profesional y encontramos lo que mejor nos funciona, que normalmente es una mezcla de éxito profesional, pero también un trabajo que tenga sentido y que vaya de la mano con nuestros valores.

text: My hot take is that for the vast majority of people, they probably do not need a coach. And what I often push people on is if you're thinking about getting a coach, which is usually an indication that they have a feeling of being stuck or they have a problem that they're trying to solve, I ask them, 'What are your goals when it comes to coaching? Roll it forward six months, what have you gotten done in your coaching experience.'
speaker: Ada Chen Rekhi
context: Lenny asks Ada about when people should get an executive coach and whether everyone needs one. Ada gives her contrarian perspective that most people don't actually need coaches. She explains that before hiring a coach, people should consider alternatives like curiosity loops for advice, courses for learning skills, or building a community for support. She challenges people to clearly define their coaching goals and consider if there are better ways to achieve them.
text_ko: 제 솔직한 의견은요, 대다수 사람들은 아마 코치가 필요하지 않을 거예요. 그리고 제가 자주 묻는 건, 코치를 고민하고 있다는 건 보통 막혀 있거나 해결하려는 문제가 있다는 신호인 경우가 많은데요, 그럴 때 저는 이렇게 물어봐요. "코칭으로 어떤 목표를 이루고 싶으세요? 6개월 뒤를 상상해 보세요. 코칭을 통해 무엇을 해냈나요?"
text_zh: 我的看法是，对大多数人来说，其实根本不需要教练。我经常会问那些想找教练的人——通常他们都是感觉卡住了或者遇到什么问题想解决——我会问他们："你找教练到底想达成什么目标？往前推六个月，你觉得通过教练指导能搞定什么事情？"
text_es: Mi opinión sin filtros es que la gran mayoría de la gente probablemente no necesita un coach. Y lo que siempre les pregunto a las personas cuando están pensando en contratar uno —que normalmente es señal de que se sienten estancadas o tienen algún problema que quieren resolver— es: "¿Qué esperas lograr con el coaching? Imagínate dentro de seis meses, ¿qué habrás conseguido con esta experiencia?"
